By applying PCA to the VIs, the algorithm identifies the most significant components that explain the variance in the data. These components capture the essential characteristics of the VIs and help in distinguishing between healthy and HLB-infected citrus trees.

By combining the PCA features of VIs with the original DN values, the models can utilize both spectral information and spatial information. The DN values represent the raw pixel intensities, which provide information about the reflectance properties of the citrus orchard. This combination allows the models to capture both the spectral and spatial patterns associated with HLB infection.

The inclusion of PCA features of VIs and original DN values improves the accuracy and agreement in all models because it provides a more comprehensive representation of the data. The models can leverage the combined information to better differentiate between healthy and HLB-infected samples, leading to more accurate classification results.
